item.title: Mocking Authentication and Authorization in ASP.NET Core Integration Tests
item.description:
ASP.NET Core makes writing integration tests very easy and even fun. One aspect that might be a bit tough to figure out is authentication and authorization. We might want to run integration tests under different users and different roles.

To get started, let’s assume we have an endpoint like this:

1app.MapGet("hi", (HttpContext httpContext) =>
2{
3    var userId = httpContext.User?.Claims?.FirstOrDefault(c => c.Type == ClaimTypes.NameIdentifier)?.Value;
4
5    return $"Hello #{userId}";
6}).RequireAuthorization();

It’s a very simple endpoint. It gets the currently logged in user’s ID and says hello to them.

item.title: Securing ASP.NET Core APIs using Auth0
item.description:
Introduction

Modern applications are complex and take many different forms: Web apps, mobile apps, desktop apps, CLI apps, other APIs, Bots, IoT apps, and so on. In this blog post we discuss what it takes for your API to let any app communicate with it securely via the OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect protocols.

By utilizing these standards, you can have a single Identity Provider protecting all of your apps. Allowing your users to sign into all of your apps using the same account, providing a seamless SSO (Single Sign On and Single Sign Out) experience. Another great benefit is you can easily allow 3rd party apps to connect to your APIs without compromising security.

item.title: ASP.NET Core API Checklist
item.description:
Building modern APIs require a lot of things to make them reliable, observable, and scalable. In no particular order, here are some of them that help you build better APIs:

Note: If you have any other points in mind, you can send me a PR here.

1. Healthchecks

Healthchecks are important in making sure that we know when anything happens to our APIs. We can setup dashboards to monitor them and setup alerting to let us know when one of the APIs is unhealthy. They are also important when deploying your apps to kubernetes. Kubernetes can monitor healthchecks of your APIs and automatically try to kill the unhealthy instances and create new instances to take their place.

item.title: Running ASP.NET Core on Linux Part 1
item.description:
